title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly identify the intermolecular forces in both compounds.

· Compound X – dispersion forces, dipole-dipole forces, and hydrogen bonding

· Compound Z – dispersion forces and dipole-dipole forces

The response correctly identifies the intermolecular forces in both compounds.

· Compound X – dispersion forces, dipole-dipole forces, and hydrogen bonding

· Compound Z – dispersion forces and dipole-dipole forces

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide a correct explanation equivalent to the following.

· The dispersion forces in each compound should be similar because they have a comparable number of electrons and similarly polarizable electron cloud. However, compound X has relatively stronger dipole-dipole forces (due to the greater number of atoms with high electronegativity) and also hydrogen bonding. Because the total of all intermolecular forces in compound X is greater than that in compound Z, compound X has the higher boiling point.

The response provides a correct explanation equivalent to the following.

· The dispersion forces in each compound should be similar because they have a comparable number of electrons and similarly polarizable electron cloud. However, compound X has relatively stronger dipole-dipole forces (due to the greater number of atoms with high electronegativity) and also hydrogen bonding. Because the total of all intermolecular forces in compound X is greater than that in compound Z, compound X has the higher boiling point.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide both the correct answer and a valid explanation equivalent to the following.

· No. The lower energy of the products relative to the reactants is consistent with an exothermic reaction, but the diagram contains too few peaks. The energy diagram of a mechanism with two elementary steps would contain two peaks, not one.

The response provides correct answer and a valid explanation equivalent to the following.

· No. The lower energy of the products relative to the reactants is consistent with an exothermic reaction, but the diagram contains too few peaks. The energy diagram of a mechanism with two elementary steps would contain two peaks, not one.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide both the correct answer and a valid justification equivalent to one of the following.

· No. The linear relationship between ln  [ C 2 H 6 O] MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43FE@ versus time is consistent with a first-order reaction, not a zeroth-order reaction.

OR

· No. The slope of the line is − 0 .20 min −1 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4385@ , which is numerically consistent with the student’s claim about the rate constant but inconsistent with the units of a zeroth-order reaction. In a zeroth-order reaction, slope=−k MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4091@ , so the units of the rate constant must be M/min MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaWGnbGaae4laiaab2gacaqGPbGaaeOBaaaa@3D4D@ rather than just min −1 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D9E@ .
